results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

In this film, Billy travels to Taiping, Malaysia and Tarakan, Borneo and then journeys throughout Australia during 1961.

This film was originally made using standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film has a few scenes from Billy’s travels to Taiping in Malaysia before moving on to Sydney and Melbourne. Billy includes some lovely scenes of being at sea, ships and shipping. The scenes in Sydney include the Harbour, the Bridge and some busy streets. In Melbourne we see the Moomba Parade, trams and vintage cars along St Kilda Road, the Yarra River and the Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southbank.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 on board ship
00:00:33:00 two passengers disembarking in Malaysia
00:00:43:00 views of traditional Malaysian housing
00:00:55:00 people cycling along roads in Taiping, Malaysia
00:01:09:00 women standing with local children in Taiping, all smiling at the camera
00:01:20:00 a woman walking toward embarkation area for a ship
00:02:12:00 great shot of a passenger ship speeding along through the water
00:03:45:00 (possibly) Pulau Pising Lighthouse on Banana Island in the Malacca Straits.
00:04:58:00 a glimpse of some passengers on board ship as they lean over the rail coming into Sydney Harbour.
00:05:43:00 a large liner at berth
00:06:10:00 military ship in Sydney Harbour
00:06:40:00 travelling over the Harbour Bridge by car
00:07:23:00 yachts on the Harbour
00:08:43:00 sign for ‘Wollongong’ followed by an early model Holden (EK)
00:12:13:00 Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southgate, Melbourne, followed by the Yarra River, river boats and Princes Bridge.
00:12:54:00 Circa 1960s (and earlier) cars and trams on St Kilda Road in Melbourne
00:13:13:00 Moomba Parade in Melbourne
00:13:39:00 a decorated ‘A.L.P’ (Australian Labor Party) parade float
00:13:43:00 the ‘Magga Dan Esberg’ ship at a berth.
00:16:50:00 Anzac Day Parade.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

In this film, Billy travels to what was then Rhodesia (Zimbabwe) and briefly visits South Africa. He films visits to the tourist spots of Victoria Falls and the Matobos National Park which may be where he captures some wonderful wandering wildlife, keeping abreast with them from a moving vehicle. Billy also captures the landscapes wherever he goes, including some public gardens, national parklands, cultivated land, hilly rocky and dry land and some lovely waterways.

This film was originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 Bulawayo Rail Station
00:00:06:00 views around the quiet town of Bulwayo including the ‘Rhodes Memorial’
00:03:23:00 some of the ‘Balancing Rocks’ of the Matobos National Park and the plaque marking the grave of Cecil Rhodes.
00:06:15:00 ‘Livingstone Memorial’
00:07:20:00 views capturing the wonderful Victoria Falls in Zimbabwe.
00:08:00:00 baobab trees
00:08:20:00 filming of wildlife begins in the (likely) Matobos National Park
00:08:51:00 herd of elephants moving through the grasses
00:08:31:00 a giraffe runs alongside the filmmaker’s moving vehicle
00:10:11:00 up close to an elephant
00:11:10:00 a zebra looking at the camera
00:13:40:00 a group of people enjoying afternoon tea
00:14:18:00 a train travels through some dramatic, dry landscape which then becomes lush and green as Billy enters South Africa.
00:14:49:00 the sign for the township of ‘Paarl’, in South Africa.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

In this film, Billy travels to the United States of America taking in the sights of Long Beach, Disneyland, San Francisco and San Diego all in California, USA.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows snippets of family life while at play, at birthday celebrations and on holiday. We see the family drive across the bridge to Phillip Island and enjoy swimming and canoeing at the beach there. The reel also includes scenes of caravan camping, koalas and a trip to the war memorial at Mount Macedon. The family enjoy games of tennis, ball games and swings and roundabouts at a playground. The film includes good examples of fashion, Austin cars and recreational activities of the time.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:01:37:00 children with their dad in the water at the beach (good example of bathing fashion)
00:02:58:00 tennis match between mum and dad
00:04:29:00 car with caravan and family in bush camp setting
00:05:14:00 Austin car with family standing at the front talking and combing hair
00:05:58:00 children being pushed on swings in a park by their mother (good fashion and sunglasses references)
00:7:30:00 close-up of little girl’s face as she blows out her birthday candles and looks to camera
00:07:41:00 family in front of war memorial at Mount Macedon
00:08:36:00 steam train travelling on a country rail line
00:08:46:00 family looking out from a ferry window
00:08:52:00 kids on a roundabout at a playground
00:09:00:00 grandmother, mother and children sitting on a playground wall – the grandmother is shooting a water pistol.
00:09:08:00 children on playground roundabout and dad jumps on to join them
00:09:32:00 a koala sitting in a tree climbs to the top and looks down
00:09:45:00 family and friends stand in front of a picket fence (good example of family groups and fashion from the time)
00:10:01:00 wide shot as cars travel across the bridge to Phillip Island

00:10:14:00 POV from inside car as it drives over the Phillip Island bridge

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Macao, China and Hong Kong in the 1960s. The quality of the film can be challenging at times (shaky, sometimes dark and damaged) but it is well worth it for scenes of the busy waterways and street life around Hong Kong Island, Kowloon and Macau. Billy particularly focuses on the many different watercraft such as passenger and cargo ships, ferries, row boats, houseboats and plenty of wonderful traditional junks.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:46:00 scenes filmed from a train as it travels past cultivated fields, farmers, bullock teams, field hands
00:01:25:00 traditional house by as river
00:01:19:00 young children working on logs at a timber mill
00:02:12:00 field workers closer to the camera
00:02:30:00 small, covered junks on the water in a harbour
00:02:45:00 busy port
00:03:05:00 large group of moored, small house boats with mountains in the background
00:03:22:00 children playing on a beach
00:03:50:00 ferries and traditional sailing boats as well as large ships
00:04:29:00 large ferry
00:04:55:00 traditional junk sailing by a large modern ship
00:05:45:00 city residential apartment buildings with mountains in background.
00:06:18:00 city streets, shops and signs, including one for ‘Coca Cola’
00:08:07:00 new and old watercraft
00:08:75:00 colourful passenger ferry
00:08:35:00 lovely traditional junk in full sail
00:09:30:00 a child points at the camera while playing with friends
00:10:00:00 international shipping
00:10:30:00 wonderful striped canvas tent bathing boxes followed by scenes of locals relaxing at the beach.
00:12:52:00 another notable traditional junk sailing by the camera
00:14:11:00 vegetable sellers in low lying boats

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

The first part of this film briefly shows an outdoor art show before moving on to water ski jumping on the Yarra River – both are part of the ‘Moomba’ celebrations. The second part shows a road trip from Glenroy to Macedon ending at ‘Cameron Lodge’, Macedon all in Victoria.

Good views of the water ski jumping and the crowds watching from the banks. The road trip shows excellent views of small towns such as Keilor and Diggers Rest, vehicles passing on country roads and roadside scenes including telegraph poles.

Extensive views of the gardens of Cameron Lodge in Macedon including the rotunda, lake, stepping stones and family scenes in the garden.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 outdoor art show
00:00:44:00 Yarra River
00:01:00:00 the ‘Moomba’ festival on the riverbank
00:01:14:00 water skiing
00:02:00:00 water skiing over a jump
00:02:30:00 crowd watching from riverbank
00:03:40:00 title card ‘Glenroy to Macedon 4-3-61’
00:03:47:00 footage of car trip filmed from moving car showing country roads
00:04:38:00 car parked next to Keilor road sign. Good views of cars on road including VW beetle and Holdens, views of telegraph poles
00:05:05:00 road bridge with curved arch
00:05:10:00 ‘Keilor Hotel’ and parked cars, street scenes
00:05:20:00 Diggers Rest town scenes
00:05:40:00 countryside from moving car
00:06:35:00 Jacksons Creek bridge
00:07:28:00 small town with parked Holdens and BP service station
00:07:46:00 title card ‘Cameron Lodge Macedon 4-3-61’
00:07:52:00 views of Cameron Lodge and man walking in gardens
00:08:24:00 views of garden rotunda
00:08:37:00 two women and baby in lodge garden
00:08:40:00 man photographing garden
00:08:47:00 man in rotunda surrounded by lake, crossing stepping stones
00:09:21:00 group walk through lush vegetation including tree ferns
00:09:46:00 walking through lodge garden
00:10:03:00 children playing in rotunda and on stepping stones
00:10:46:00 group of children and adults on lakeside steps
00:11:10:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 168]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows downhill, cross-country and slalom skiing at Mt Buller, Victoria, including the Women’s National Ski Competition in August 1947 and 1948 (according to notes on the donated original film can). There are good views including a horse drawn sled, snow fashion of the era and a ski lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Some of the footage is overexposed.

Selected highlights list
00:00:02:00 downhill ski race, various competitors filmed from a fixed camera position
00:02:40:00 views of snowed covered mountains
00:02:50:00 skiers in distance going downhill, possible slalom
00:03:46:00 better footage of downhill slalom
00:04:36:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis, views of mountain and ski lodge
00:04:49:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis
00:04:58:00 good footage of horse drawn sled
00:05:06:00 skiers walking wearing skis
00:06:50:00 group cross country skiing with sled
00:06:58:00 man strapped to sled (possibly injured or practising)
00:07:08:00 man gets off sled at ski lodge amid group of skiers
00:07:17:00 close up views of skiers at lodge showing fashions of the era
00:07:35:00 people riding horse drawn sled
00:07:44:00 downhill skiing
00:08:32:00 dining room in ski lodge full of diners (waitress in uniform)
00:09:03:00 mountain views
00:09:40:00 horse riding
00:10:38:00 man standing by car loaded with skis

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria including views of Melbourne, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory (A.C.T).

This film shows a road trip of over 2,000 miles (3,200 kms) through south-east Australia in a Riley motor car in the early 1950s.

Excellent scenes of country driving and towns visited including Lakes Entrance, Boydtown, Eden, Canberra, Echuca, Cohuna and Renmark before returning to Melbourne.

Opening with the title ‘The Dream Car’ a dream of a new car brings it to reality in a melodramatic piece and the travellers set off on their road trip.

Excellent views of the Riley car (appears to be a 1951 model), cars of the era in various towns and a very undeveloped Canberra and institutions such as the original National Library building and the Australian War Memorial.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 37]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows some wonderful car racing in Victoria and South Australia in 1953 and 1955. Includes the Templestowe and Rob Roy hill climbs, races at Altona and Baxter Park, and the Grand Prix at Port Wakefield.

While some footage is overexposed there are good scenes of the cars and spectators. Drivers shown include Jack Brabham, Reg Hunt, Kevin Neal and Doug Whiteford. Brabham is shown winning the 1955 Australian Grand Prix.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list
00:00:00 KenRa opening title
00:00:10 ‘Why the hurry fellows’ title card
00:00:17 6th Templestowe Hill Climb, 17th May 1953 brochure shown. Card filmed from several fixed locations
00:01:27 car stuck at side of track. Spectators inspect and car is towed free.
00:04:46 picnic at side of track
00:07:37 spectators in pith helmets
00:07:51 Rob Roy Hill Climb car sticker
00:07:56 views of spectators
00:08:06 people inspecting card
00:08:20 cars racing on track (overexposed) – Rob Roy
00:09:10 cars racing on track (exposure better)
00:09:28 group of men standing by car
00:10:19 view of spectators on hillside
00:10:31 parade of cars on track
00:11:55 brochure for Baxter Park races in Frankston (very overexposed)
00:12:03 racing around dirt track – Baxter Park, Frankston
00:12:30 tractor grading track
00:14:10 cars preparing to race
00:14:58 spectators stand on and around wooden tray truck
00:15:05 trick motorcycle riding
00:17:59 ‘Altona car racing Sunday June 6’ poster in car window
00:18:03 cars racing at Altona
00:18:35 mechanics working on car engine
00:21:09 close up of parked racing card and spectators
00:21:30 loading car on to truck tray
00:21:43 ‘The end’ title card
00:21:48 colour footage starts – KenRa opening title card
00:21:59 ‘Practice & qualifying heats Port Wakefield 1955’ title card
00:22:08 mechanics work on car then push it to track
00:22:22 racing on track
00:22:40 close up cars and engines
00:23:08 close up Reg Hunt’s car
00:28:28 mechanics working on cars. Possibly Jack Brabham
00:29:14 ‘Australian Grand Prix Port Wakefield 1955’ title card
00:29:26 Grand Prix, Port Wakefield, South Australia
